title: Poolsbrook Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Path round Poolsbrook Lake by Kate Jewell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: David Rogers / Poolsbrook Country Park
images.caption: The Park was developed on the site of the former Ireland Colliery. This 180 acre park includes 85 acres of woodland 42 acres of grassland and 23 acres of green water.

images.title: Entrance Sign, Poolsbrook Country Park by Paul Shreeve, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Entrance Sign

images.title: Stuart Widdowson / Poolsbrook Country Park
images.caption: Looking out towards Lowgates, with Poolsbrook Lake in the valley.

images.title: Cafe, Poolsbrook Country Park by Paul Shreeve, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cafe

images.title: Stuart Widdowson / Pools Brook Pond
images.caption: Looking South at the Pond formed by Pools Brook as it flows down to Poolsbrook Country Park.

images.title: Residential street in Poolsbrook by Andrew Hill, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Residential street in Poolsbrook village. The village was established by the Staveley Coal and Iron Company towards the end of the 19th century. It was built to provide housing for workers employed at the nearby Speedwell and Ireland Collieries. Over time, as the need for more housing arose, new houses were constructed, which the locals refer to as the "new village." The original houses, which were part of the initial construction, have since been demolished. This pattern of development is typical of many industrial villages in the UK, where housing was often provided by the company to ensure that workers lived close to their place of employment. The shift from old to new housing reflects changes in the needs and standards of living over the years.

images.title: Meadows Drive, entrance to Pools Brook country park by Steve Fareham, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Meadows Drive, entrance to the park.

description: This 180 acre park consists of 85 acres of woodland, 42 acres of grassland and 23 acres of green water. There are several miles of well maintained paths suitable for cyclists or walkers. The park is located in Staveley, very near to Chesterfield and the village of Duckmanton. To extend your walk you can head north from the park and link up with the Chesterfield Canal. You could then follow a nice section of the canal into Chesterfield. The Cuckoo Way long distance trail also runs to the north of the park. Follow it north and you will come to Eckington's Renishaw Hall and Rother Valley Country Park .

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: There's a good on site cafe where you can enjoy a range of meals and snacks after your exercise.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The park is ideal for a dog walk so expect to see plenty of other owners on a fine day.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: For more walking ideas in the area see the Derbyshire Walks page.
